questions.question: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of thedorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsalduct usually persists as an accessory duct.In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreaticbuds leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). Pancreatic drainage isaccomplished mainly through the accessory papilla.Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, the pancreasdivisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to thedevelopment of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitisDorsalbileGalanlagebladderVentralanlageDuodenumNormalPancresOMARROWLivergutporsal anlageVentral ankageGall bladderMidgutDorsalvontraMinorcommon bile ductAccessonsduct ofSantoriniMein &APSTRMajor papillaCommon bile ductduct OTVinumal duct of

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of pancreatic divisum?

options.B: Pancreatojejunostomy is also known as Puestow's procedure
options.D: ERCP is more advantageous than MRCP for the diagnosis

questions.explanation: MRCP is more advantageous than ERCP in diagnosing pancreatic divisum. This is because,MRCP can delineate the entire dorsal pancreatic duct, whereas ERCP can assess only the ventralduct on cannulation of the major duodenal papilla.The diagnosis of pancreatic divisum can also be made by EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injectionof secretin if necessary.Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgicalintervention may involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or evenresection of the pancreatic head.The image given below shows an MRCP done for a case of pancreatic divisum.817Gall bladderDorsal ductCommon bile ductFailure of fusionVentral duct

questions.question: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrentnon-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed secondportion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the followingstatements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
options.B: Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
options.C: Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
options.D: MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmentalanomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of theduodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not anMRCP.The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventralpancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or thirdpart of the duodenum.GallbladderDuodenumAnnularpancreasAnnular pancreasStomach-JejunumSuperior mesentericartery and veinOMARROWIt is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, moreprevalent in children with Down's syndrome.818Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates.Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it isnon-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CTscan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing APremains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and thehead of the pancreas.The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).

questions.question: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with sudden onset abdominal pain in the epigastricregion radiating to the back. The pain relieves on leaning forwards. X-ray abdomen shows no809gas under the diaphragm. Elevated amylase levels and total WBC count are seen. Which ofthe following signs are likely to be present in this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Rovsing sign and Aaron sign are seen inacute appendicitis.Rovsing sign: Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant.Aaron sign: Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with firm pressure applied toMcBurney's point.In severe acute pancreatitis, the injured pancreas releases pancreatic enzymes that cause fatnecrosis and inflammation, occasionally resulting in peri-pancreatic bleeding. The resulting fluidcollection can travel via an anatomical defect of the transversalis fascia. This accumulates atvarious sites and shows discoloration of the skin.Cullen's sign: If the blood diffuses from the retroperitoneum along with the gastrohepatic andfalciform ligaments to the umbilicus, it results in bluish discoloration around the umbilicusGrey Turner sign: If the blood diffuses from the posterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of thequadratus lumborum muscle, it results in bluish discoloration of the flanksFox sign: Pooling of retroperitoneal hemorrhage at the inguinal ligament showsdiscoloration below the inguinal ligamentBryant sign: Pooling of blood at the scrotum

questions.question: What is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is the presence of gallstones (50-70%). The secondmost common cause is alcohol abuse (25%).Causes of acute pancreatitis: (Mnemonic: I GET SMASHED)⚫ I - Idiopathic• G - Gallstones•⚫ E - Ethanol• T – Trauma•-• S – Steroids-⚫ M – Mumps, malignancy (pancreatic cancer)819• A - Autoimmune•·S - Scorpion sting⚫ H - Hypercalcemia, hypertriglyceridemia (Usually more than 1000 mg/dL)•⚫E - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)•⚫ D - Drugs

questions.question: A patient presenting with acute abdomen was found to have elevated serum amylase levels.Which of the following should be part of your differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation: All the above conditions should be part of the differential diagnosis in patients with acuteabdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels.Conditions associated with elevated serum amylase levels:• Burns•Pregnancy• Pancreatitis•Cholecystitis•• Diabetic ketoacidosis• Ruptured ectopic pregnancy• Aortic aneurysm• Renal failure• Renal transplantation•Chronic liver disease• Intestinal obstruction•Drugs like morphine•Salivary gland involvement: mumps, calculus, maxillofacial surgery•Tumors of the lungs, esophagus, breast, or ovary (LEBO)

questions.question: All of the following derangements can be expected in a patient with acute pancreatitis except:
questions.explanation: Acute pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of freefatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels ofcirculating calcium.Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acutepancreatitis.820

questions.question: 810Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.explanation: Alvarado scoring is used in acute appendicitis, not acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis usingRanson's criteria, except:
questions.explanation: Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson's criteria, not 250 IU/L.

questions.question: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of:
questions.explanation: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis.Revised atlanta classification:Mild Acute Pancreatitis•No organ failure• No local or systemic complicationsModerately Severe Acute Pancreatitis• Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or• Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failureSevere Acute Pancreatitis• Persistent organ failure (>48 hours) - Single organ or multiorgan

questions.question: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.explanation: A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acutepancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.Common causes of gasless abdomen include:•High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia• Small bowel obstruction•• Bowel ischemia• Ascites• Acute pancreatitis• Gastroenteritis• Large abdominal mass - due to displacement•Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anteriorresection821•A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adultsNote: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas inthe right iliac fossa.

questions.question: 811A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominalpain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the backand is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient isgiven below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.explanation: The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the leftside. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via thetransverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the coloncut-off sign.All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding usage of the contrast-enhanced CT scanin cases of acute pancreatitis?

options.A: It is the investigation of choice
options.B: It should be done within 72 hours from the onset of symptoms
options.C: Balthazar criteria is used to stage the severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan
options.D: Signs of sepsis is an indication for CT scan

questions.explanation: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitisis more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimatethe extent of necrosis.A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice in acute pancreatitis. However, it is notperformed in all cases of pancreatitis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis:•Diagnostic uncertainty• In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis• In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration• When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or apseudoaneurysmThe image below is a CT scan from a patient with acute exudative pancreatitis.822The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

questions.question: A patient with acute pancreatitis underwent a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. CTscan shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas without necrosis. What will be the CTseverity index of the patient?812
questions.explanation: The CT severity index (CTSI) of this patient will be 1.The CT severity index for grading of acute pancreatitis is determined as the sum of two scores:• Balthazar score: grading of pancreatitis•• Necrosis score: grading of the extent of pancreatic necrosisThe Balthazar score for diffuse enlargement of the pancreas is 1. Since there is no necrosis, thenecrosis score of the patient is zero. Hence the CTSI of this patient is 1.

questions.question: When will you use the SOFA score in a patient with acute pancreatitis?

options.B: To assess the need for surgery
options.C: In cases of pancreatic abscess formation
options.D: To assess the length of hospital stay

questions.explanation: The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score is used to assess organ failure in acutepancreatitis. The three organ systems most frequently involved are the cardiovascular,respiratory, and renal systems. Multiple organ failures are said to exist when 2 or more organsregister 2 or more points on these scoring systems.qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infectionwho are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses threecriteria, assigning one point each for••• Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg)High respiratory rate (° 22 breaths per min)• Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15)823The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple promptto identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presented with a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe abdominal painwith radiation to the back. He gives a history of binge drinking on the night prior to hissymptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable and there is no sign of organ impairment. Hisserum amylase level is 500 U/L (normal: 23-85 U/L) and lipase level is 1100 U/L (normal:10-140 U/L). Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: CECT abdomen is almost always necessary to establish the diagnosis
options.B: CT should be performed 72 hours after the onset of symptoms to assess complications
options.C: Modified marshall scoring system can be used to assess the severity of organ failure
options.D: Early initiation of enteral nutrition is beneficial for overall improvement of prognosis

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with characteristic lab findings is suggestive of acute pancreatitis.CECT abdomen is not always necessary to diagnose acute pancreatitis.According to the revised Atlanta classification, acute pancreatitis is clinically defined by at leastthe first two of three features:••abdominal pain suggestive of pancreatitis (epigastric pain often radiating to the back),⚫ serum amylase and lipase levels ° 3 times normal (imaging is to be used if the elevated valuesare less than 3 times normal); and●• characteristic imaging findings on CT, magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, or transabdominalultrasonographic (US) studies.If acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of the first two criteria with no systemic sign ofsevere systemic inflammatory response syndrome or persistent organ failure, contrastmaterial-enhanced CT may not be necessary for determining patient care.Option B: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acutepancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT mayunderestimate the extent of necrosis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis are•• Diagnostic uncertaintyIn patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis• In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration• When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or apseudoaneurysmOption C: For severe acute pancreatitis with systemic inflammatory response syndrome andpossible organ impairment, the modified marshall scoring can be used to assess the severity oforgan failure. It includes respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal systems scores. A score of morethan 2 for any organs indicates organ failure. Revised Atlanta classification recommends themodified Marshall scoring system as the main tool in determining organ failure.Option D: Current evidence confirms that the administration of enteral nutrition is beneficial forthe treatment of severe acute pancreatitis. Enteral feeding reduces mortality, infectiouscomplications, and multiorgan failure. In terms of the timing of enteral nutritional support,relatively early administration within 48 or 72 h of hospital admission is suggested.

questions.question: A patient with pancreatitis is likely to develop all of the following vascular complications,except:

options.B: Splenic artery aneurysmGastroduodenal artery aneurysmd) Mesenteric artery thrombosis813Question 18:A chronic alcoholic presented with complaints of progressive abdominal distension. His pasthistory is significant for acute pancreatitis which was managed by supportive care. USGabdomen showed peri-pancreatic ascitic fluid collection. A large volume paracentesis (LVP)was performed. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?a) The ascitic fluid will be low in protein.b) Amylase levels in the fluid are raised.
options.C: Somatostatin will help in decreasing secretion.

questions.explanation: Mesenteric artery thrombosis is unlikely in patients with acute pancreatitis.The most common vascular complication following acute pancreatitis is arterial pseudoaneurysm.824

questions.question: A young lady presents with acute epigastric pain and vomiting. She also gives a history ofpain and swelling over the right parotid gland for 3 days. USG abdomen revealsperipancreatic ascitic fluid collection. Which of the following is not true about the fluidcollection?

options.A: It is not associated with fibrous wall
options.B: The most common vessel involved is the splenic artery

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis caused due to mumps. Hemosuccuspancreaticus in acute pancreatitis is not associated with ascites.Hemosuccus pancreaticus is due to the erosion of the wall of the pancreatic pseudocyst into thesplenic artery forming a direct communication. It presents with abdominal pain and uppergastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, without ascites.In contrast to pseudocysts and cystic neoplasias of the pancreas, fluid collections are notsurrounded or encased by epithelium or fibrotic capsules.Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipaselevels.Most fluid collections will be spontaneously reabsorbed by the peritoneum. Treatmentinvolves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding andadministration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdominal drainage combined with the endoscopicplacement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done.If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure ofthe proximal stump is done.

questions.question: A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following binge drinking. 7-dayspost-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBCcount of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue.How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings aresuggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage.A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity tothe pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected.825Clinical features include:• Fever with chills• Elevated white blood cell count•• Abdominal painContrast-enhanced CT scan and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosisand abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/orperipancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection.Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imagingguidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

questions.question: 814Which of the following will not be part of the management plan of patients with infectedpancreatic necrosis?
questions.explanation: Infected pancreatic necrosis should not be managed conservatively with antibiotics alone becauseof the high risk of multiorgan failure and death.CT scan has to be performed in patients with severe acute pancreatitis, organ failure, sepsis, andin patients with clinical deterioration despite the treatment:•• If the CT scan shows the presence of sterile pancreatic necrosis medical management isrecommended.• If the CT scan shows the presence of necrosis with evidence of infection, then ultrasound orCT-guided aspiration of the fluid has to be done and the fluid is sent for staining and culture.Infected pancreatic necrosis is treated by the administration of intravenous antibiotics (preferablycarbapenems) and percutaneous drainage of the infected fluid. Pancreatic necrosectomy is beconsidered in the patients if the clinical condition worsens despite percutaneous drainage.

questions.question: Regarding the revised Atlanta classification for morphologic stages of acute pancreatitis, which of the following is not true?

options.A: Acute necrotic collection is non-encapsulated necrosis within 4 weeks of onset
options.B: Acute peripancreatic fluid collection can be seen in interstitial edematous pancreatitis
options.C: Pancreatic pseudocyst can be seen in necrotizing pancreatitis
options.D: A collection that contains non-liquefied material is more likely to become infected

questions.explanation: Pancreatic pseudocyst is seen as a sequela of interstitial edematous pancreatitis, which is a non-necrotic collection. Necrotizing pancreatitis usually leads to acute necrotic collection (ANC) and walled-off necrosis (on encapsulation of ANC). Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and its collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation. Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis (IEP), Acute Peripancreatic Fluid Collection (APFC): non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks, pancreatic pseudocyst: non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks), and Necrotizing Pancreatitis. Acute Necrotic Collection (ANC): necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks, Walled-Off Necrosis (WON): necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks). ANC, APFC, WON, and pancreatic pseudocysts can be infected or non-infected. Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas are more likely to be infected. Duration since onset: <4 weeks after onset (not encapsulated), undergoes encapsulation → 4 weeks after onset (encapsulated): IEP → APFC, Necrotizing pancreatitis → ANC → Pancreatic pseudocyst/WON.

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl was rushed to the casualty after she was injured by a bicycle's handlebar inthe abdomen. She complains of severe epigastric pain. On examination, bruises are seen inthe epigastrium. Her CT scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false abouther condition?815

options.B: Distal pancreatectomy will be the definitive management.
options.C: Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a handlebar injury and the CT scan showing transection of thebody of the pancreas are suggestive pancreatic injury. Plasma amylase levels are not sensitive inpancreatic injuries.The most common mechanism of pancreatic injury in children is blunt trauma (because of thedecreased amount of fat and incomplete protection of the rib cage). In adults, penetrating injuriesare the most common cause. Involvement of other organs is also likely to be seen.Direct compression of the epigastrium against the vertebral column and a blunt object (handlebar)is typically seen after bicycle injuries. The most common segment of the pancreas affected is thebody.Patients usually present with epigastric pain. In some cases, a delayed presentation may be due toleakage of pancreatic fluids.The modality of choice is the CT scan of the abdomen. If there is doubt about duct disruption, anurgent ERCP or MRCP should be done.Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted. A damage control procedure withpacking and drainage should be performed initially and the patient referred for definitive surgeryafter stabilization.•Definitive management includes:• Distal pancreatectomy - If the body or tail is involved• External drainage - If the head of the pancreas is involved• Pancreatoduodenectomy - If the pancreatic head and duodenum is involved827
